A001.explanation: Kandyan Sword (Kasthne) Overview This royal ceremonial sword originates from Sri Lanka and dates to 17thâ€“18th century. Materials and Craftsmanship Forged steel blade; brass/silver hilt; wood; gemstone inlays Function and Use Used in royal ceremonies, investitures, and as visible rank insignia. Carried by nobles during processions and occasionally used in ritualized demonstrations of martial skill; also part of diplomatic gift exchanges. Cultural Significance Embodies royal authority, protector role of the king, and the martial lineage of Kandaan aristocracy. The Makara/dragon motifs mark protective power and link to mythical guardians. Special Features Hilt often shaped like a Makara (mythical sea-creature). Many examples show inlay work, ceremonial scabbards, and are inscribed or gifted as diplomacy tokens; some blades were intentionally blunted for ceremonial use. This artifact represents an important piece of cultural heritage, showcasing the craftsmanship, beliefs, and practices of its time and place.
